docs.text:
About


ThreatLab
 is a PCAP analysis tool that uses 
Snort
 and 
Suricata
 to scan network packet captures.


EmergingThreats
 rules are used for generating alerts.


Pagination


ThreatLab API uses "Limit-Offset" pagination.
The client includes both a "limit" and an "offset" query parameter. 
The limit indicates the maximum number of items to return. The default limit size is 10. 
The offset indicates the starting position of the query in relation to the complete set of unpaginated items.


Request example:


GET http://www.threatlab.io/api/pcap/v1/3dbcaa40-cd9b-4fdf-87ec-8cf226e582ff/alerts/?limit=5
offset=5




Response:


{
    
count
: 10,
    
next
: null,
    
previous
: 
http://www.threatlab.io/api/pcap/v1/3dbcaa40-cd9b-4fdf-87ec-8cf226e582ff/alerts/?limit=5
,
    
results
: [
        ...
    ]
}




APIs




You can interact and test the APIs in your browser:


http://www.threatlab.io/api/console/




PCAP Upload


Upload PCAP file for analysis


/api/pcap/v1/upload/{filename}
  


Method: 
PUT






Parameter


Data Type


Required


Description






filename


String


Yes


File name







Testing with CURL


curl 'http://www.threatlab.io/api/pcap/v1/upload/' --upload-file ~/Downloads/sample.pcap




Sample response body


{
    
id
: 
f7c14dc9-100d-4a01-8c9e-fe7e40b7c548

}




PCAP Status


PCAP analysis status


/api/pcap/v1/{id}/status/
    


Method: 
GET






Parameter


Data Type


Required


Description






id


String


Yes


Upload ID







Sample response body


{
    
status
: 
READY

}




PCAP Detail


PCAP object details.


/api/pcap/v1/{id}/
  


Method: 
GET






Parameter


Data Type


Required


Description






id


String


Yes


Upload ID







Sample response body


{
    
id
: 
3dbcaa40-cd9b-4fdf-87ec-8cf226e582ff
,
    
status
: 
READY
,
    
is_private
: false,
    
created
: 
2015-10-07T21:47:51.224781Z
,
    
alerts
: 
http://www.threatlab.io/api/pcap/v1/3dbcaa40-cd9b-4fdf-87ec-8cf226e582ff/alerts
,
    
errors
: 
http://www.threatlab.io/api/pcap/v1/3dbcaa40-cd9b-4fdf-87ec-8cf226e582ff/errors

}




PCAP Alerts


IDS alerts generated during analysis.


/api/pcap/v1/{id}/alerts/
  


Method: 
GET






Parameter


Data Type


Required


Description






id


String


Yes


Upload ID







Sample response body


{
    
count
: 7,
    
next
: null,
    
previous
: null,
    
results
: [
        {
            
text
: 
ET EXPLOIT Possible Internet Explorer VBscript failure to handle error case information disclosure CVE-2014-6332 Common Function Name
,
            
protocol
: 
TCP
,
            
classification
: 
Attempted User Privilege Gain
,
            
priority
: 1,
            
src_ip
: 
157.193.55.183
,
            
dst_ip
: 
192.168.96.10
,
            
src_port
: 80,
            
dst_port
: 1042,
            
tool
: 
SURICATA

        },
        ...
    ]
}




PCAP Errors


Errors logged during analysis.


/api/pcap/v1/{id}/errors/
    


Method: 
GET






Parameter


Data Type


Required


Description






id


String


Yes


Upload ID







Sample response body


{
    
count
: 2,
    
next
: null,
    
previous
: null,
    
results
: [
        {
            
error
: 
Invalid file format
,
            
tool
: 
SNORT
,
            
pcap
: 
http://www.threatlab.io/api/pcap/v1/3dbcaa40-cd9b-4fdf-87ec-8cf226e582ff

        },
        ...
    ]
}

docs.text: ThreatLab  is a PCAP analysis tool that uses  Snort  and  Suricata  to scan network packet captures.  EmergingThreats  rules are used for generating alerts.

docs.text:
ThreatLab API uses "Limit-Offset" pagination.
The client includes both a "limit" and an "offset" query parameter. 
The limit indicates the maximum number of items to return. The default limit size is 10. 
The offset indicates the starting position of the query in relation to the complete set of unpaginated items.  Request example:  GET http://www.threatlab.io/api/pcap/v1/3dbcaa40-cd9b-4fdf-87ec-8cf226e582ff/alerts/?limit=5 offset=5  Response:  {
     count : 10,
     next : null,
     previous :  http://www.threatlab.io/api/pcap/v1/3dbcaa40-cd9b-4fdf-87ec-8cf226e582ff/alerts/?limit=5 ,
     results : [
        ...
    ]
}

PCAP object details.  /api/pcap/v1/{id}/     Method:  GET    Parameter  Data Type  Required  Description    id  String  Yes  Upload ID    Sample response body  {
     id :  3dbcaa40-cd9b-4fdf-87ec-8cf226e582ff ,
     status :  READY ,
     is_private : false,
     created :  2015-10-07T21:47:51.224781Z ,
     alerts :  http://www.threatlab.io/api/pcap/v1/3dbcaa40-cd9b-4fdf-87ec-8cf226e582ff/alerts ,
     errors :  http://www.threatlab.io/api/pcap/v1/3dbcaa40-cd9b-4fdf-87ec-8cf226e582ff/errors 
}

docs.text:
IDS alerts generated during analysis.  /api/pcap/v1/{id}/alerts/     Method:  GET    Parameter  Data Type  Required  Description    id  String  Yes  Upload ID    Sample response body  {
     count : 7,
     next : null,
     previous : null,
     results : [
        {
             text :  ET EXPLOIT Possible Internet Explorer VBscript failure to handle error case information disclosure CVE-2014-6332 Common Function Name ,
             protocol :  TCP ,
             classification :  Attempted User Privilege Gain ,
             priority : 1,
             src_ip :  157.193.55.183 ,
             dst_ip :  192.168.96.10 ,
             src_port : 80,
             dst_port : 1042,
             tool :  SURICATA 
        },
        ...
    ]
}

PCAP Errors

docs.text:
Client Libraries


Python


slumber


Slumber is a python library that provides a convenient yet powerful object orientated interface to ReSTful APIs. It acts as a wrapper around the excellent requests library and abstracts away the handling of urls, serialization, and processing requests.


Source: 
https://github.com/samgiles/slumber


Usage example:


 import slumber

 ## Connect to http://www.threatlab.io/api/pcap/v1/ with no authentication

 api = slumber.API(
http://www.threatlab.io/api/pcap/v1/
)

 ## GET http://www.threatlab.io/api/pcap/v1/pcap/f7c14dc9-100d-4a01-8c9e-fe7e40b7c548

 api.pcap('f7c14dc9-100d-4a01-8c9e-fe7e40b7c548').get()

 ## GET http://www.threatlab.io/api/pcap/v1/pcap/f7c14dc9-100d-4a01-8c9e-fe7e40b7c548/alerts

 api.pcap('f7c14dc9-100d-4a01-8c9e-fe7e40b7c548').alerts().get()
docs.title: Clients

docs.text: slumber  Slumber is a python library that provides a convenient yet powerful object orientated interface to ReSTful APIs. It acts as a wrapper around the excellent requests library and abstracts away the handling of urls, serialization, and processing requests.  Source:  https://github.com/samgiles/slumber  Usage example:   import slumber  ## Connect to http://www.threatlab.io/api/pcap/v1/ with no authentication  api = slumber.API( http://www.threatlab.io/api/pcap/v1/ )  ## GET http://www.threatlab.io/api/pcap/v1/pcap/f7c14dc9-100d-4a01-8c9e-fe7e40b7c548  api.pcap('f7c14dc9-100d-4a01-8c9e-fe7e40b7c548').get()  ## GET http://www.threatlab.io/api/pcap/v1/pcap/f7c14dc9-100d-4a01-8c9e-fe7e40b7c548/alerts  api.pcap('f7c14dc9-100d-4a01-8c9e-fe7e40b7c548').alerts().get()
